data.title: Integrated terminal pty.js dependency build issue
data.body:
See https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/pull/5985 and https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/143

The integrated terminal warns this when opened:

```
Cannot find module '../build/Release/pty.node'
```

This is happening because the build of the pty.js module fails so it falls back on pre-built packages. The strange thing about this is that the build only fails when `./scripts/npm.sh install --arch=x64` (Linux) is run over the whole repository, but it builds just fine after this when explicitly running install on the module:

```
~/dev/Microsoft/vscode/node_modules/pty.js @tyriar/integrated_terminal +24/-2
❯ npm run install

> pty.js@0.3.0 install /home/daimms/dev/Microsoft/vscode/node_modules/pty.js
> node scripts/install.js

make: Entering directory '/home/daimms/dev/Microsoft/vscode/node_modules/pty.js/build'
  CXX(target) Release/obj.target/pty/src/unix/pty.o
  SOLINK_MODULE(target) Release/obj.target/pty.node
  COPY Release/pty.node
make: Leaving directory '/home/daimms/dev/Microsoft/vscode/node_modules/pty.js/build'


> pty.js@0.3.0 postinstall /home/daimms/dev/Microsoft/vscode/node_modules/pty.js
> node scripts/post-install.js
```

data.title: Fix German Translation of "Tabs"
data.body: It's "Tabstopp" which is already used in line 10, and not "Registerkarte", which is a valid translation, but semantically different (browser tab vs. indentation tab).

data.title: Disk name in ${workspaceRoot} is lowercase may result in a bug related to node6, webpack and babel
data.body:
- VSCode Version: v1.1
- OS Version: windows 10
- nodejs Version: v6

Steps to Reproduce:
( a little bit complicate)
1. mkdir try-bugs && cd try-bugs 
2.npm install -g vue-cli
2.vue init webpack
3.npm install
4.set up a task in task.json, whose command is `npm`, args is `["run", "build"]`
5. press `contrl + shift + b` to build the project
6.then babel of webpack does not work in the right way
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3315274/15247779/e2c30e2a-1948-11e6-85ef-065a9c4bb524.png)

Further description and guess:
I have install a extension of vscode called [new-cmd ](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=odonno.new-cmd), which can enable you to open a new terminal from current work space directory by typing command `cmd` after pressing `f1` in vscode.
If I open a terminal using this extension and then run `npm run build` in this terminal, it will show me the same bug as run the build task from vscode.
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3315274/15247757/cc4b29d4-1948-11e6-98da-07de74a8b956.png)

However, if I open a terminal manually by right click and run the same command, everything goes well.
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3315274/15247842/53734e96-1949-11e6-9f70-fee948c954c0.png)

I notice that there is one difference between the two terminal is that the disk name. The disk name in former terminal is `d:\` while the later one is `D:\`. 
In the project, from one hand, there are some code, the config of webpack specifically, related to `path.join(__dirname, ...)`, which will generate an absolute path to files begin with `D:\`. From the other hand, there are some other code use relative path to locate file, which will result in path to file begin with `d:\`.
I wonder whether this caused my problem or not.
By the way, if I repeat the process with node5, the bug disappear.

data.title: OSX - Not able to overwrite workbench.action.closeWindow keybinding
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.1.0
- OS Version: OSX 10.10.5

Hi there,

First of all, thanks for all the great work around VS Code!

I'm having an issue with overriding keybinding for `cmd+w` (which by default closes currently opened tab). I'm trying to define following bindings in order to mimic the IntelliJ IDEA bindings:

```
|| Key              || Action                           ||
| cmd + w           | editor.action.smartSelect.grow    |
| cmd + shift + w   | editor.action.smartSelect.shrink  |
| cmd + f4          | workbench.action.closeWindow      |
```

Unfortunately, putting them into my keybindings doesn't result in any change.

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Press F1 and select _Preferences: Open Keyboard Shortcuts_
2. Put the following into your keybindings definition:
   
   ```
   // Place your key bindings in this file to overwrite the defaults
   [
       {
           "key": "cmd+f4",
           "command": "workbench.action.closeWindow",
           "when": "editorTextFocus"
       },
       {
           "key": "cmd+w",
           "command": "editor.action.smartSelect.grow",
           "when": "editorTextFocus"
       },
       {
           "key": "shift+cmd+w",
           "command": "editor.action.smartSelect.shrink",
           "when": "editorTextFocus"
       }
   ]
   ```
3. Restart VS Code
4. Try to expand selection using `Cmd+W`. 

**Expected result:**
Keystroke expands smart selection.

**Actual result:**
Currently opened window closes.

data.title: REPL: reveal auto-expanded objects
data.body:
- VSCode Version: alpha

Steps to Reproduce:
- start debugging
- fill the debug console so that a new entered expression appears at the bottom of the REPL
- type 'process'

Observe:
process is auto expanded but not revealed. This will make the user try to expand the object which in fact will make it collapse.

I suggest to reveal the auto expanded object at the top of the debug console.

data.title: ES6 template strings declared at the end of a ternary operator are incorrectly parsed
data.body: - VSCode Version: 1.1.0 - OS Version: OS X 10.11.4 Steps to Reproduce: 1. Create a new text file `test.js` 2. Set the content to the following: ``` js let x = true ? '' : `${1}` console.log('still part of the template!') ``` VS Code fails to parse the opening ``` of the template string at the end of the ternary operator correctly. It therefore sees the final ``` as an opening tick, and interprets the rest of the file as a template string: As a workaround you can wrap the failure case in parenthesis: ``` js let x = true ? '' : (`${1}`) console.log('still part of the template!') ```

data.title: Javascript Code Format Indentation not always correct
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.1.0
- OS Version: Debian Stretch

There is a glitch of the (otherwise very perfect) Javascript Code Format:

Steps to Reproduce:
0. (Set "editor.tabSize": 2 for using 2 spaces as indentation)
1. save this as a .js file

```
    var series = [{
      name: 'One',
      data: []
    }, {
        name: 'Two',
        data: []
      }, {
        name: 'Three',
        data: []
      }
    ];
```
1. Press Ctrl+Shift+i to format code 
2. The Object named One will not get indented correctly.
3. Indent it manually, so it is aligned with Two and Three.
4. Press Ctrl+Shift+i
5. Object One is misaligned again.

It does not understand how to format an object in this way (used in highcharts for example)
It works however if the first '{' is written in an extra line (which I do not like).

I may sound picky, but this is the first code formatter, that I actually use extensively and so I really care! It formats nicely without interfering too much!
Thank you!

If someone doesn't like the default key combination they can change it, but generally developers try to launch developer tool by pressing F12 or Ctrl +F12 or something like that (though it is not Browser).

data.title: Support process environment per opened window

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.1.0 (c212f0908f3d29933317bbc3233568fbca7944b1)
- OS Version: Windows 10 TP5

When the first instance of VSCode opens, it inherits the environment from whatever context it was opened from.  Any subsequent instances do not inherit their environment, instead copying the one loaded by the first instance.  So if the first instance is launched from explorer against a random file, while the second one is launched from a cmd window that has GO and GIT configured in the path, the second one will insist that GO and GIT are missing from the environment.  Reversing the order fixes the issue.

Even though inheriting environment from other open instances may provide some speed boost for opening, each new instance should inherit its environment from the context it was launched in order to preserve expected behavior for users.

Quick repro (using golang extension from https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=lukehoban.Go):
1. Unset GOPATH environment variable in shell.
2. Launch vscode, observe the yellow warning in the lower right indicating that GOPATH is not set.
3. Set the GOPATH environment variable correctly.
4. Navigate to a new folder and launch vscode again

Expected:
GOPATH should be loaded.

Actual:
GOPATH is still not detected because environment is inherited from first instance.

data.title: No apparent way to get column for a visible editor
data.body:
As of VSCode API Version: 0.11.0, it seems to be impossible to get column of the active editor from a TypeScript extension.

This is quite strange considering typings for `vscode.window.showTextDocument()`:

``` typescript
/**
 * Show the given document in a text editor. A [column](#ViewColumn) can be provided
 * to control where the editor is being shown. Might change the [active editor](#window.activeTextEditor).
 *
 * @param document A text document to be shown.
 * @param column A view column in which the editor should be shown. The default is the [one](#ViewColumn.One), other values
 * are adjusted to be __Min(column, columnCount + 1)__.
 * @return A promise that resolves to an [editor](#TextEditor).
 */
export function showTextDocument(document: TextDocument, column?: ViewColumn): Thenable<TextEditor>;
```

Could you please add a `viewColumn` property to the `TextEditor` interface?

See https://github.com/bbenoist/vscode-togglehs/issues/2 for the initial reasons of my request

data.title: Getting exception "This socket has been ended by the other party" wen debuggin extension.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.1.0-alpha
- OS Version: Windows10

I am not certain if this is the real issue with product or not. But thought to give heads up if something we need to handle at API level.

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Generate VSCode extension project  using Yeoman
2. Open VS code and open generated folder.
3. Start debugging by following instruction mentioned at  https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/extensions/example-hello-world
4. Verify debug point hit under extension project once you try to add hello world extension.
5. Try to execute "extension install command" from command palette in newly launched instance of VSCOde and then clean all the text using backspace key.
Actual: Getting exception: ""This socket has been ended by the other party""
Expected: There should not be any exception triggered when you perform common operations on newly launched VSCode instance.
![extensiondebuggingissue](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17735796/15222549/1e4741fc-1825-11e6-88c3-fc2de86b2e5b.gif)
